columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the Net Present Value of the processes using the given data. After that, we will solve for the different break-even points as well as the degree of operating leverage for each process.

For Process I, the operating cashflow is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\$345-\$85) \times 450,000-\$81,000,000]\\
&\times(1-0.21) +(0.21 \times (\$75,000,000/7))\\[15 pt]
&=\$30,690,000
\end{aligned}$$

For Process II, the operating cashflow is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\$345-\$137) \times 450,000-\$63,000,000]\\
&\times(1-0.21) +(0.21 \times (\$55,000,000/7))\\[15 pt]
&=\$25,824,000
\end{aligned}$$

For Process III, the operating cashflow is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\$345-\$182) \times 450,000-\$48,000,000]\\
&\times(1-0.21) +(0.21 \times (\$36,000,000/7))\\[15 pt]
&=\$21,106,500
\end{aligned}$$
For the annuity factor, we can use an annuity table and check for the factor corresponding to $7$ years with $13\%$ required return. The annuity factor will be $4.4226$

For the net present value of Process I:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=-\$75,000,000+(\$30,690,000 \times 4.4226)\\[15 pt]
&=\$60,729,594
\end{aligned}$$

For the net present value of Process II:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=-\$55,000,000+(\$25,824,000\times 4.4226)\\[15 pt]
&=\$59,209,222.40
\end{aligned}$$

For the net present value of Process III:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=-\$36,000,000+(\$21,106,500\times 4.4226)\\[15 pt]
&=\$57,345,606.90
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see here, Process I has the highest NPV.

For Process I:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Q}_{\text{accounting}}&=\dfrac{\$81,000,000+\$10,714,285.71}{\$345-\$85}\\[15 pt]
&=352,747.25
\end{aligned}$$

For Process II:
$$\begin{aligned}

For Process III:

&=326,029.80

For Process I:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Degree of Operating Leverage}&=1+\dfrac{\$81,000,000}{\$30,690,000}\\[15 pt]
&=3.6393
\end{aligned}$$

This means that a $1\%$ increase in the quantity will yield to a $3.6393\%$ increase in the operating cashflow

For Process II:
$$\begin{aligned}

This means that a $1\%$ increase in the quantity will yield to a $3.4396\%$ increase in the operating cashflow
